newsitem.title: GERMANY: Beiersdorf plans restructuring, cut jobs.
newsitem.headline: Beiersdorf plans restructuring, cut jobs.

text.p: German specialty chemicals and consumer products group Beiersdorf AG on Wednesday announced deep restructurings but said these would not impact this year's dividend level.
It added it expected to pay a one mark dividend for 1996.

In a mandatory bourse statement, Beiersdorf, best known for its Nivea skin care products, said it would set aside 200 million marks for the restructuring, which is expected to weigh on pre-tax profits.
But the group also said "the company's healthy structure allows it to tackle these problems and (it) expects no impact on its current dividend level."

The restructuring will involve streamling the group's portfolio and concentrating on a smaller number of business areas. This will result in 700 jobs being lost over the next three years, Beiersdorf said.
"The management board expects to regain profitability for its tesa (adhesives) unit and restore the entire group's earnings momentum with these measures," Beiersdorf said.

In the first quarter 1997 Beiersdorf reported a 3.3 percent rise in sales, generated solely by foreign turnover. The group said foreign sales jumped 9.1 percent while domestic sales fell by 5.8 percent. The group did not give absolute figures.
Beiersdorf, like many German consumer care groups, has been adversely affected by Germany's ongoing sluggish consumer demand, dampened during the last recession.
Beiersdorf earlier reported that its 1996 turnover climbed 8.1 percent to 5.7 billion marks with profits reaching 233.8 million marks.
The group plans to pay a one mark dividend per share, nominally valued at five marks, Beiersdorf said.
